titleStmt.title: Love without measure. Or, The young-mans delight, and the maidens joy. This youngman woo'd a damosel fair, and call'd her his joy and dear, but she was coy, as maids will be, and said he came with flattery. But he did protest it was not so, and at last brought her unto his bow: now they live in love, in peace, and joy, and she very fain would have a boy. To a rare new tune, called, Du-Vals delight.

Love without measure. Or, The young-mans delight, and the maidens joy. This youngman woo'd a damosel fair, and call'd her his joy and dear, but she was coy, as maids will be, and said he came with flattery. But he did protest it was not so, and at last brought her unto his bow: now they live in love, in peace, and joy, and she very fain would have a boy. To a rare new tune, called, Du-Vals delight.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for VV[illiam]. Thackery, and T[homas]. Passinger.,

notesStmt.note: Verse: "Late in the country as I was walking ..."
Date, place of publication and publisher's names from Wing.
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University, Houghton Library.
